title: 6.2: Vector Operations
summary: Learn advanced vector operations including length calculations and vector math
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn advanced vector operations for particle systems. You'll create a complete particle system from scratch that demonstrates vector length calculations, normalization, and how to use vector math to create sophisticated particle behaviors.
steps: Create a SystemBlock - this is the root of your particle system
Create a CreateParticleBlock to emit particles
Set an initial color and size using ParticleInputBlock
Add a <filter-value>CylinderShape</filter-value> block to emit particles from a cylinder volume
Add an UpdatePositionBlock to handle particle movement
Get Position and ScaledDirection, add them together, and connect to UpdatePositionBlock
Add a ParticleVectorLengthBlock to calculate the length of the direction vector
Connect ScaledDirection to the vector input of ParticleVectorLengthBlock
Use the vector length to affect particle size (faster particles = larger)
Multiply the length by a size factor to create the size multiplier
Add UpdateColorBlock and connect InitialColor contextual value to it
Add UpdateSizeBlock and combine base size with the size multiplier
Chain the blocks: CreateParticle → CylinderShape → UpdatePosition → UpdateColor → UpdateSize → System
Add a ParticleTextureSourceBlock to provide a texture
Observe how particle size varies based on movement speed

blocks.name: ParticleVectorLengthBlock
blocks.description: Calculates the length (magnitude) of a vector. Useful for distance calculations, speed measurements, and vector normalization.

properties.name: vector
properties.description: The vector whose length will be calculated

properties.name: length
properties.description: The calculated length of the vector

codeCopy: Vector operations are essential for advanced particle effects. ParticleVectorLengthBlock calculates the magnitude of a vector, which represents distance or speed. This can be used to create effects where particle properties (like size or color) change based on how fast the particle is moving. The formula for vector length is: length = sqrt(x² + y² + z²).
objectives: Calculate vector lengths for distance and speed measurements
Use vector length to affect particle properties
Combine vector operations with other calculations
Apply vector math to create sophisticated effects

commonMistakes.explanation: Vector length is always positive (distance). Using it directly for effects that need negative values or specific ranges can cause issues.
commonMistakes.solution: If you need normalized values or specific ranges, multiply or divide the length by appropriate factors. Remember: length is always >= 0.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not understanding what vector length represents
commonMistakes.explanation: Vector length represents distance or magnitude, not direction. It's a scalar value, not a vector.
commonMistakes.solution: Use vector length for distance-based effects, speed calculations, or when you need to normalize vectors. For direction, use the vector itself.

homework: Create particles that change color based on speed
Use vector length to create distance-based effects
Combine vector length with age-based calculations
Experiment with normalizing vectors for consistent directions
Create effects where size varies with movement speed
